title.narrative: Parliamentarians for Global Action Core Support 2013-2015

description.narrative: Parliamentarians for Flobal Action (PGA), parlamentariker för globalt deltagande och utveckling är ett nätverk bestånde av nu valda ocvh sittande riksdagmän från ca 130 länder (medlemskap på ca 1000 st.). De arbetar med att tackla frågor av internationell betydelse. Syftet är att att verka för fred, demokrati, rättsstatens principer, mänskliga rättigheter samt hållbar utveckling.

Parliamentarians for Global Action (PGA) is an international network of legislators with a membership of approx. 1000 MPs from 130 countries globally. They are all elected an in office currently. Their aim is to tackle issues of international importance. The overall objectives of PGA's programmes are to promote peace, democracy, rule of law, human rights and sustianble development

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: Over the last two years, PGA grew from less than 900 to more than 1,300 members in 143 parliaments. The global network of individual MPs is supported by a PGA National Group structure in parliaments, which creates sustainability and ownership of campaigns at the national level, and by an international secretariat with relevant expertise.
This increase was made possible by a more focused implementation of the 2013-2015 Strategic Plan, marked by new leadership of the secretariat from January 2014, and a review of programs and campaigns that culminated in a new three-year Strategic Plan (2016-2018). All programmes and actions of PGA are incorporated into result-oriented campaigns for:
1. International Law and Human Rights (ILHR) Programme: 1.1. Effectiveness and Universality of the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court (ICC) System 1.2 Abolition of the Death Penalty 2. Gender, Equality and Population (GEP) Programme: 2.1 End Child, Early and Forced Marriage (CEFM) 2.2 Non-Discrimination Based on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity (SOGI) 3. Peace and Democracy (P&D) Programme: 3.1 Ratification and Implementation of the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT) and the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention (BTWC)
PGA campaigns are characterised by concrete action based on analysis on the global, regional and national levels. An MP who is initially engaged by PGA through the ICC Campaign, can prove to be an effective advocate in her country on the Arms Trade Treaty (ATT), Abolition of the Death Penalty or Non-Discrimination Campaigns. PGA is also an organization that provides a safe space for MPs, where they can share experiences through PGA’s peer-to-peer methodology.
Three cross-cutting issues are of major importance to PGA: The Sustainable Development Goals and especially Goal 16 to “Promote peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development, provide access to justice for all and build effective, accountable and inclusive institutions at all levels,” and Goal 5 to “Achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls.” This latter goal also taps into the second cross-cutting issue of gender equality. The third cross-cutting issue is the shrinking democratic space for civil society organizations.
During the last few years, PGA has also diversified its funding base and augmented its budget within the parameters of internal fiscal control.
It is Sida's assessment that PGA, with the changes above, has strengthened its capacity to deliver results toward the intended outcome, and that PGA is more focused in its work. The assessment is furthermore that PGA contributes to the creation of a rules-based international order for a more equitable, safe and democratic world, in accordance with its intended outcome.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
